. The term originated in the days of Islam's great expansion; it means 'the west' in Arabic, and referred to all the Islamic areas beyond

.

Today the term is applied to all of the Mediterranean coast of Africa except Egypt, plus the Atlas mountains inland from there and some areas along the Atlantic coast. In European histories, much of the region is often called the Barbary Coast; names for its people include Berbers and Moors. When the Moors ruled them,
would have been counted as part of the Maghreb.
